title: Princeton Student Edward Tian Built GPTZero to Detect AI-Written Essays

last_post.content:
these "GPT-detection" approaches bother me quite a bit, mostly because they don't actually detect GPT or LLMs (they can't). so, instead, they consider the statistical likelihoods around regularity, and then ask humans to interpret some weird "probabilities" related to that, which we know humans are terrible at.

i was teasing @lowd because one of this recent creative toots was judged to be 75% likely to have been generated by a LLM. no way people know how to use that.

title: Attributed Question Answering: Evaluation and Modeling for Attributed Large Language Models

last_post.content:
I think attribution is pretty important (I just helped write a paper about it!). Of course Yoav is right that in human writing we usually add sources long after we’ve decided what we want to say. But for most use cases, it seems like a good idea to hold LMs to a higher standard. Anecdotally, i’ve found that non-experts often think ChatGPT “must be” doing search, even though it’s not.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08037

title: Thoughts on the new scaling laws for large language models

last_post.content:
DeepMind's paper refutes this last claim, and finds that both are equally useful.
The differences between DeepMind & OpenAI's papers matter in terms of forecasting how big LLMs need to get. They arrived at these different conclusions because DeepMind did more learning rate tuning. This blog post https://severelytheoretical.wordpress.com/2022/07/18/thoughts-on-the-new-scaling-laws-for-large-language-models/ hypothesizes that DeepMind's paper might also be not doing enough hyperparameter tuning, and the scaling law may be less severe, perhaps not even a power law.
3/3

title: The turtle moms that ‘talk’ to their eggs before they hatch

last_post.content:
Ok, this is cool: a team of biologists worked out that turtles can talk. The hatchlings even talk to each other in the egg to coordinate their hatching. Turtle talk is at frequencies not very audible for humans and it can take hours for some species to reply to each other.

“Had we had a bit more expansive imaginations, we might have caught this earlier,” said Karen Bakker, a fellow at Harvard’s Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2023/01/06/turtles-eat-south-america/

title: Banned in the USA: The Growing Movement to Censor Books in Schools

last_post.content:
Was just doing research for a book I #amwriting and discovered that in the U.S., over 1600 #books were banned in school libraries in 2022 -- as compared to just 175 being "challenged" in 2015 (books that are challenged are rarely banned, according to the American Library Association, so the numbers of banned books that year were much lower).

In 2022, 41% of books were banned for LBGT content. 40% had BIPOC characters.

Citations:
2022: https://pen.org/report/banned-usa-growing-movement-to-censor-books-in-schools/

2015: https://www.ala.org/advocacy/bbooks/frequentlychallengedbooks/statistics/2015infographiclong

title: This Is How They Wiped Themselves in Ancient Rome - JSTOR Daily

last_post.content:
I've been researching how ancient civilizations cleaned their butts after pooping (I'm writing a book!) and y'all, the Ancient Greeks were SUPER punk rock. They used bits of broken ceramic like a scoop (don't worry - the edges were smoothed out) and sometimes THE BITS OF POTTERY WERE INSCRIBED WITH THE NAMES OF THEIR ENEMIES.

They literally wiped their butts with their enemies' names. I am in awe.

https://daily.jstor.org/this-is-how-they-wiped-themselves-in-ancient-rome/#:~:text=Ancient%20Greeks%20exiled%20their%20enemies,%2C%E2%80%9D%20it%20was%20a%20curse.
Cybiko - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybiko

A copperplate print - on paper. Across early modern Europe, most printed images were made with a woodblock or a copperplate. These "new images", as Hans Belting coined them, were a good-selling product in Europe from 1500 onward.

En passant: The painter, Cornelis N. Gijsbrechts, made himself appear in the painting. You see his self-painted portrait covered as a print of the media ensemble. That's an intermedia comment, by the way: https://www.francoangeli.it/rivista/getArticoloFree/71598/It

6/10

title: The world's in a 'polycrisis' — and these countries want to quash it by looking beyond GDP

last_post.content:

title: File:Cornelis Norbertus Gijsbrechts - An Open Cupboard Door - 1665.jpg - Wikimedia Commons

last_post.content:
So much paper in this 1665 painting from Cornelis N. Gijsbrechts. You see an open cupboard door, as art history labelled the image, but what you also see: prints, letters, a broadside, an almanac, stored unused paper sheets. Early Modern Europe was a paper age. Gijsbrechts' painting has it all: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cornelis_Norbertus_Gijsbrechts_-_An_Open_Cupboard_Door_-_1665.jpg

Let's focus on this in more detail, dear #paperhistory, and bookhistory experts, and #histodons interested in the material worlds of the past. Here we go, next paper thread.

1/10

#Zotero & Mastodon tricks:
1. Bc Mastodon is using standard HTML, Zotero is able to recognize any DOIs in your current timeline & import the related works into your Zotero library:
Right-click on the Save to Zotero icon in your browser and select "Save to Zotero (DOI)"
2. Did you know you can add individual Mastodon posts with metadata to Zotero when you're looking at a single post view, e.g. by clicking on the timestamp (the URL will look sth like https://fediscience.org/@adam42smith/109639860471806025 )
